TopicTitle: You Know You're A Nerd When:

Articles.Content:
when:

- hey brain could you give me a break
- sure i can, that's a yes
- ... nice try ... thks anyway ... it's all about the intent i guess
When you have 1,916 screenshots, and half of them are from this forum.

you grab all the caracter set you can find here and there, before now and then
you grab words that describe the way to move of various danse
you grab pronounciation tone , and face zygomatic mimic and orginal/melted localisaion of sound (throat, stomach, nose, etc.) for eash single word, caracter and languages you can
shape of sentence and lisibility per homogeneity and ceach single caracter differenciation when associated together
geo politico socio model over ages here and there, evolution rate @  lambda t
((((( etc )))))

insert in spad/alike software or messed brain then push "n" dimensionnal correlation button, then watch the resultings graphicsssssssssssss ............. and bang you head on the wall around the concept of dna appplied to socio psycho code deeply socio binded thing & communication, via ideo picto phonogramm and there association and differenciation since neandhertal and it's pal's

Edited January 4, 2017 by WinkAllKerb''

When you create/use a mod simulating a virtual flight to keep safe you virtual (!) ships.

When you create/use a mod to leisurely play tetris while "flying" in a virtual ship inside a game.

 

Edited January 5, 2017 by kerbiloid

-When everyone living with you asks you IT questions.

-When you own retro consoles and your a teen.

-when you can read a big book over a few nights.
I'm 54.... but my daughter buys me collectible action figurines for Christmas, not the other way around... lmao....

I've got the entire Empire vehicle series of the Titanium set from Micromachines. None of that "first order" garbage, but the Galactic Empire!

And yes my wife and my six year old daughter gave me two new Empire vehicles for Hanukkah...From the movie, "Rogue One." Oh, and I'm 46!

Edited January 5, 2017 by adsii1970

3 hours ago, Kombat engineer said:

-when you can read a big book over a few nights.

I used to demolish 1000+ page Stephen King books, such as Tommyknockers, It, or The Stand, in a week. Before modern PCs, of course.

when "we can resurect them, how, ... *laugh/giggles* i don't know"ben burtt clone war making off while speaking of old magnetic soundtrack from the first star wars

Edited January 6, 2017 by WinkAllKerb''
When the first thing you do in the morning is turning on your computer.

10 minutes ago, ZentroCatson said:

When the first thing you do in the morning is turning on your computer.

Why do you turn it off?

53 minutes ago, kerbiloid said:

Why do you turn it off?

The standby light is kinda annoying me when I'm in bed. Its pretty bright and flashes constantly. Also my computer turns on really fast

When instead of asking you friends "would you prefer to die from being electrocuted or burned?" you ask "If you had to chose between Dioxygen Difluoride, Chlorine Trifluoride, Plutonium Hexafluoride, Sodium Nitrite, Hydrogen Sulfide, and Hydrocyanic acid, what would you chose to survive?" (Don't ask. Also, yes I actually asked them this.) 

Edit: and when have a two and a half page long list of chemicals that will kill you. again, don't ask (feel free to ask me). 

Edited January 6, 2017 by max_creative
Feel free to ask me. :P

When you are an American and you can remember the mass of the Sun in kg, the Sun's radius in meters and the semi-major axes of all of the planets in meters, but can't for the life of you remember any of those things in pounds and miles

when a sure there was no, ui but all the math behind was oki ... i used to be land surveyor after all for a few year ... also i don't type a single a line since 25 years, but when you ve done assembly in straight hexa, that's not really hard to see behind the code without typing any line of code (notice tha my neuronal scheme slighty messed up in the process "slighty")

not intended but well ....

We haven't had the periodic table around for a while, so here goes...

When you can recite this on demand: Hydrogen, helium, lithium, beryllium, boron, carbon, nitrogen, oxygen, fluorine, neon, sodium, magnesium, aluminum, silicon, phosphorous, sulfur, chlorine, argon, potassium, calcium, scandium, titanium, vanadium, chromium, manganese, iron, cobalt, nickel, copper, zinc, gallium, germanium, arsenic, selenium, bromine, krypton, rubidium, strontium, yttrium zirconium, niobium, molybdenum, technetium, ruthenium, rhodium, palladium, silver, cadmium, indium, tin, antimony, tellurium, iodine, xenon, cesium, barium, lanthanum, cerium, praseodymium, neodymium, promethium, samarium, europium, gadolinium, terbium, dysprosium, holmium, erbium, thulium, ytterbium, hafnium, tantalum, tungsten, iridium, platinum, gold, mercury, thallium, lead, bismuth, polonium, astatine, radon, francium, radium, actinium, thorium, protactinium, uranium, neptunium, plutonium.

Also, when you start doing the math for a proper equation for burn time, accounting for changing mass, on a scrap of paper while waiting for a 6 minute burn to complete.
When your math teacher uses your work as an answer key.

When you tell people to contact you through IRC because it's easier to use than SMS. 

When you have the full flight manual for the SR-71 and you don't even have a pilot's license, or access to an SR-71.

On 12/21/2016 at 9:02 PM, kerbiloid said:

When you pass Turing test.

More like when you can't pass the Turing test because you can't hold social interactions for more than a few minutes with most of your peers.

On 1/10/2017 at 6:00 PM, ThatSpaceyGamer said:

When you tell people to contact you through IRC because it's easier to use than SMS. 

When you have the full flight manual for the SR-71 and you don't even have a pilot's license, or access to an SR-71. 

Okay, where in the world did you get a flight manual for a Blackbird?

I need one of these.
When you correct your science teacher, they correct you, then you do research on the topic to find definite evidence of photons having momentum despite not having mass. I won the debate.
